isis.stitle: DIAMONDLIFE™ (BOSCH PIN SLIDE) DISC BRAKES For Vehicles Built Before June 3, 2002 - install - ROTOR AND WHEEL HUB ASSEMBLY

svcsubproc.title: Install

step1.para:
Install front rotor onto wheel hub (Items 12 and 8, Figure 30)
and (Items 12 and 8, Figure 31)
by installing retaining nuts and washers (Item 14, Figure 30)
or retaining bolts, washers and nut (Item 13, Figure 31)
securing them together. Refer to TORQUE CHART
for proper tightening specifications.

Install rear rotor onto wheel hub (Items 11 and 7, Figure 32)
and (Items 11 and 7, Figure 33)
by installing retaining nuts (Item 12, Figure 32)
or retaining bolts, washers and nuts (Item 12, Figure 33)
securing them together. Refer to TORQUE CHART
for proper tightening specifications.

On front axles, for installation of rotor and wheel hub assembly (Items 12 and 8, Figure 30)
and (Items 12 and 8, Figure 31) , refer to GROUP 02 - FRONT AXLE in the Master Service Manual for proper rotor and wheel hub assembly installation along with bearings and related components.

On rear axles, for installation of rotor and wheel hub assembly (Items 11 and 7, Figure 32)
and (Items 11 and 7, Figure 33) , refer to GROUP 14 - REAR AXLE in the Master Service Manual for proper rotor and wheel hub assembly installation along with bearings and related components.

note.para:
Several changes have been incorporated within the anchor plate assembly and caliper mounting bolts on vehicles manufactured after June 3, 2002. It is important to recognize that these changes are not found on disc brakes on vehicles manufactured before June 3, 2002, unless a complete rebuild of the anchor plate assembly was performed on the vehicle. The components that have changed are the leading and trailing guide pins (Figure 67)
and (Figure 68)
and caliper mounting bolts (Figure 71) .

caution.para:
When servicing vehicles manufactured before June 3, 2002, it is recommended that the old guide pins (Figure 67)
be replaced with the new leading and trailing guide pins (Figure 68)
that are used on vehicles manufactured after June 3, 2002. Because of the differences in guide pins effective with brakes used on vehicles manufactured after June 3, 2002, any replacement of the guide pins should be done in pairs and the correct mounting bolts (Figure 71)
and torque must be used. Refer to CALIPER, Install
for proper torque requirements.

note.para:
If the old leading and trailing guide pins (Figure 67)
are being replaced with new leading and trailing guide pins (Figure 68)
as recommended below, it is NOT necessary to remove the anchor plate and splash shield from the vehicle to replace the guide pins.

svcsubproc.para:
Refer to Figure 27
for Items in parentheses.

step1.para: Remove lower (bottom) hex mounting bolt (Item 2) securing the caliper (Item 1) to the anchor plate (Item 4) and remove caliper from anchor plate, position caliper out of the way on the vehicle suspension. Secure caliper assembly with a tywrap so that it does not fall. Be sure brake hose does not kink and does not support the weight of the caliper, driver side front brake shown.

svcsubproc.para:
Refer to Figure 76
for Items in parentheses unless otherwise noted.

step1.para:
Before installing caliper, visually inspect anchor plate (Item 1) for damage or defects to mating surfaces at anchor plate pad abutment slippers (Item 2), anchor plate tie bar (Item 3), if so equipped (73 mm brakes only) and check guide pin heads (Item 4). If guide pin heads are the same (Figure 67) , the vehicle was manufactured before June 3, 2002. You can tell the old guide pins from the new guide pins by looking at the head of the guide pins. The old guide pin heads will look the same, the new trailing guide pin head will have a notch on each side of the rounded sides of the head. If the old guide pins are found, it is recommended that new leading and trailing guide pins (Figure 68)
used on disc brake assemblies of vehicles manufactured after June 3, 2002 be installed before installing caliper. If the guide pins are being replaced, refer to ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Disassemble
, ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Clean and Inspect
and ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Assemble
to remove and install guide pins.

If old guide pins (Figure 67)
are being replaced with the new guide pins (Figure 68) . Pull guide pin boots (Item 5) off anchor plate (Item 1) or old guide pins and check for damage or defects. If damage or defects are found, they must be replaced. If guide pin boots are not damaged or defective, wash them in soapy water and dry them. Once again, after the guide pin boots have been cleaned and dried, inspect them for damage or defects. If damage or defects are found, they must be replaced. Refer to ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Disassemble
, ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Clean and Inspect
and ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Assemble
to remove and install guide pin boots.

figure.caption: Figure 76. Inspect Anchor Plate for Damage or Defects

important.para: Check new hex flanged mounting bolts for adhesive patch (Figure 71) , if no adhesive patch is found, apply a small patch of liquid loctite 2440 to the area indicated as adhesive patch in (Figure 71) . For best loctite 2440 performance, surfaces should be clean and free of grease. Loctite should be applied to the bolt in sufficient quantity to fill all engaged threads. Loctite develops usable strength within 1 hour and full strength at room temperature in 3 hours.

svcsubproc.para:
Refer to Figure 72
for Items in parentheses.

step1.para: Once the new leading and trailing guide pins have been installed. Position caliper (Item 1) in place at lower mounting and align flat on guide pin head (Item 2) with the flat on caliper guide pin boss (Item 3), then install the new lower (bottom) hex flanged mounting bolt (Item 4) securing the caliper to the anchor plate (Item 5). Tighten to finger tight, driver side front brake shown.

figure.caption: Figure 77. Install Inboard and Outboard Disc Brake Pads

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 77 for Items in parentheses.

step1.para: If old disc brake pads are being reinstalled, position inboard and outboard disc brake pads (Items 1 and 2) on front brakes and (Items 3 and 4) on rear brakes, onto anchor plate pad abutment slippers (Item 5) with the lining facing toward the rotor (Item 6), driver side front and rear brake shown. Using markings made during removal be sure to install disc brake pad back on the same wheel it was removed from and also in the same inboard and outboard location.

caution.para:
The HX-7A1-EE inboard and outboard disc brake pads (Items 1 and 2, Figure 78) are not interchangeable. The word "FORWARD" and the "ARROW" markings on the brake pads backing plate show forward rotation direction of the rotor (Item 4, Figure 78). The arrow MUST point in the forward rotor rotation direction (Figure 79). The optional HX-402-EE and SOFTER lining brake pads inboard and outboard disc brake pads (Item 4, Figure 59)
are interchangeable between the inner and outer locations.

figure.caption: Figure 78. Inboard and Outboard Disc Brake Pads Marking of Arrow and Forward

calloutgroup.callout1: DRIVER SIDE REAR BRAKE PADS (73 mm) SHOWN

figure.caption: Figure 79. Install Inboard and Outboard Disc Brake Pads (HX-7A1-EE with Arrow in Forward Rotor Rotation Direction)
Figure 80. Rotate Caliper Closed About Lower Hex Mounting Bolt and Guide Pin

step1.para:
Carefully rotate the caliper (Item 1, Figure 80) closed about the lower (bottom) hex flanged mounting bolt and guide pin (Items 2 and 3, Figure 80). Refer to DISC BRAKE PADS, Install
.

svcsubproc.para:
Refer to Figure 34
for Items in parentheses.

step1.para: Install anchor plate tie bar (Item 1), if so equipped (73 mm brake assembly only), to anchor plate (Item 2) by installing 12-point head bolts (Item 3). Tighten to 40 to 50 ft-lbs. (54 to 68 N•m).

Install wheel (tire and rim) on vehicle and remove floor stands. Refer to GROUP 17 - WHEELS in the Master Service Manual for proper wheel installation. Refer to TORQUE CHART
for proper tightening specifications based on mounting hardware size and thread type.

note.para: When installing the wheel (tire and rim) on disc brake axles, make sure the tire valve stem clears the brake caliper. The use of a valve stem retainer or a tire manufacturer's stem forming tool are the only acceptable methods of obtaining clearance when necessary.

step1.para: Check the master cylinder reservoir and fill if necessary. Refer to GROUP 10 - LUBRICATION in the Master Service Manual for proper brake fluid.
After any brake service, be sure to test brakes prior to returning vehicle to service. A firm pedal should be felt during brake application.

If necessary, bleed brakes, Refer to BLEEDING INSTRUCTIONS
.
